sea:
Ocean has the same denotation as sea but the latter has many additional
connotative qualities* Sea is an older word in the English language—we
my find it occurring in the oldest writings in the language, whereas
ocean^entered English much later in history—with the normal invasion of
the British Isles* Sea has many poetic connotations, while ocean is a
more objective, even scientific term c.f*, oceanogsraiahy*
tides
Originally, time and tide had almost the same meaning. As the English
language developed, tide'became more specific in its denotations, and is
used to refer to the periodic rise and fall of the ocean, (flood tide and
high tide contrasted with ebb tide and low tide)* It retains its original
meaning of "time1* in certain compounds referring to seasons or periods of
the year—winter tide* yule tide*
